MARKDOWN Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: ### Understanding CLAUDE.md The `CLAUDE.md` file in your project root acts as a persistent system prompt that shapes Claude's behavior throughout your session. **Basic CLAUDE.md structure:**
Language: markdown
Code:
# Project: E-commerce Platform

## Tech Stack
- Next.js 14 with App Router
- TypeScript strict mode
- Prisma with PostgreSQL
- Tailwind CSS + Radix UI

## Coding Standards
- Use functional components with hooks
- Prefer named exports over default exports
- All functions must have JSDoc comments
- No any types - use proper TypeScript

## File Organization
- Components: src/components/{feature}/{Component}.tsx
- API routes: src/app/api/{resource}/route.ts
- Utilities: src/lib/{category}.ts

## Testing Requirements
- Unit tests with Vitest
- E2E tests with Playwright
- Minimum 80% coverage for new code

chunks.title: MARKDOWN Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Advanced CLAUDE.md Patterns **Pattern 1: Behavioral Constraints**
Language: markdown
Code:
## Behavioral Guidelines

### Code Changes
- NEVER modify package.json without explicit permission
- ALWAYS run tests after making changes to core modules
- PREFER extending existing code over rewriting

### Security
- NEVER log sensitive data (passwords, tokens, PII)
- ALWAYS use parameterized queries for database operations
- REQUIRE input validation on all API endpoints

### Performance
- AVOID N+1 queries - use eager loading
- PREFER lazy loading for components over 50KB
- LIMIT API responses to 100 items by default

chunks.title: MARKDOWN Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: - LIMIT API responses to 100 items by default ``` **Pattern 2: Domain Knowledge**
Language: markdown
Code:
## Business Logic

### Order Processing
Orders go through these states:
1. pending -> Payment not yet received
2. confirmed -> Payment successful, awaiting fulfillment
3. processing -> Items being picked and packed
4. shipped -> Handed to carrier
5. delivered -> Customer received order
6. cancelled -> Order was cancelled (refund issued)

### Pricing Rules
- Discount codes: Applied before tax
- Shipping: Free over $100, otherwise $9.99
- Tax: Calculated based on shipping address state

chunks.title: MARKDOWN Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: - Tax: Calculated based on shipping address state ``` **Pattern 3: Error Prevention**
Language: markdown
Code:
## Common Pitfalls to Avoid

### Database
- User.findUnique() can return null - always handle it
- Prisma transactions are required for multi-table updates
- Soft delete: Set deletedAt, don't use DELETE

### API
- Rate limiting is 100 req/min per API key
- Webhook signatures must be verified
- Pagination is required for list endpoints

### Frontend
- useEffect dependencies must be complete
- Form state needs optimistic updates for UX
- Images need width/height for CLS prevention

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: ## Multi-Turn Conversation Strategies ### Building Context Progressively **Round 1: Establish understanding**
Language: text
Code:
Let's work on the checkout flow. First, walk me through how
the current CartContext works - I want to make sure we're
aligned before making changes.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: aligned before making changes. ``` **Round 2: Define the problem**
Language: text
Code:
Good analysis. The issue is that cart updates are slow because
we're refetching the entire cart on each change. Let's design
an optimistic update strategy.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: an optimistic update strategy. ``` **Round 3: Implement iteratively**
Language: text
Code:
That approach looks good. Implement the optimistic update for
addToCart first. We'll handle removeFromCart in the next round.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: addToCart first. We'll handle removeFromCart in the next round. ``` **Round 4: Refine and polish**
Language: text
Code:
The implementation works but I noticed the loading state flickers.
Add a minimum 200ms delay before showing the spinner to prevent
flash of loading content.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Context Anchoring When returning to a topic, anchor Claude's memory:
Language: text
Code:
Earlier we discussed the authentication middleware that validates
JWT tokens and handles refresh. Let's extend that to support
role-based access control. The middleware is in src/middleware/auth.ts.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Branching Conversations Explore alternatives without losing context:
Language: text
Code:
Let's explore two approaches:

OPTION A: Server-side rendering the user dashboard
- Pros: SEO, initial load performance
- Cons: Server load, cache complexity

OPTION B: Client-side rendering with SWR
- Pros: Simpler, real-time updates
- Cons: Slower initial load, no SEO

Analyze both for our use case (10k daily users,
mostly authenticated pages).

chunks.title: MARKDOWN Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: ### Using Hooks for Automation Claude Code supports hooks that run automatically at specific points: **.claude/hooks/pre-commit.md:**
Language: markdown
Code:
Before committing, always:
1. Run `pnpm lint` and fix any issues
2. Run `pnpm test:unit` to verify no regressions
3. Check for console.log statements and remove them
4. Verify no TODO comments without issue references

chunks.title: MARKDOWN Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: 4. Verify no TODO comments without issue references ``` **.claude/hooks/post-file-edit.md:**
Language: markdown
Code:
After editing any file in src/components/:
1. Check if the component has a corresponding .test.tsx
2. If tests exist, verify they still pass
3. If tests don't exist and the component has >20 lines, suggest adding tests

chunks.title: MARKDOWN Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: ### Custom Slash Commands Create reusable workflows: **.claude/commands/review-security.md:**
Language: markdown
Code:
# Security Review

Perform a security audit of the specified file or directory.

## Checklist
- [ ] Input validation on all user inputs
- [ ] SQL injection prevention (parameterized queries)
- [ ] XSS prevention (output encoding)
- [ ] CSRF protection on state-changing endpoints
- [ ] Authentication checks before sensitive operations
- [ ] Authorization checks for resource access
- [ ] Sensitive data exposure (logs, errors, responses)
- [ ] Rate limiting on authentication endpoints

## Output Format
Provide findings as:
| Severity | Location | Issue | Recommendation |

chunks.title: MARKDOWN Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: | Severity | Location | Issue | Recommendation | ``` **.claude/commands/implement-feature.md:**
Language: markdown
Code:
# Feature Implementation

Given a feature description, implement it following our standards.

## Process
1. Analyze requirements and ask clarifying questions
2. Design the solution (data model, API, UI)
3. Implement in order: types, data layer, API, UI
4. Write tests for critical paths
5. Update documentation if public-facing

## Standards
- TypeScript strict mode
- No any types
- Comprehensive error handling
- Accessibility compliance

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Conditional Instructions Use conditional logic in your prompts:
Language: text
Code:
Implement the user profile edit feature.

IF the user.role is "admin":
  - Allow editing all fields including role
  - Add audit log entry for changes
ELSE:
  - Only allow editing name, email, avatar
  - Require current password to change email

IF process.env.NODE_ENV is "production":
  - Rate limit to 10 updates per hour
  - Send email notification on email change
ELSE:
  - No rate limiting
  - Skip email notifications

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ## Meta-Prompting ### Self-Correction Instructions
Language: text
Code:
After writing code, review it with these criteria:
1. Would a junior developer understand this?
2. Are there any edge cases not handled?
3. Could this break existing functionality?
4. Is there unnecessary complexity?

If you find issues, fix them before presenting the solution.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: If you find issues, fix them before presenting the solution. ``` ### Confidence Calibration
Language: text
Code:
Rate your confidence in this solution:
- HIGH: Well-established pattern, tested approach
- MEDIUM: Reasonable approach, some assumptions made
- LOW: Novel solution, needs validation

For LOW confidence items, explain what could go wrong and
how we would verify the solution works.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: how we would verify the solution works. ``` ### Thinking Out Loud
Language: text
Code:
For this complex refactoring task:
1. First, explain your understanding of the current code
2. Identify all the files that will be affected
3. List the order in which changes should be made
4. For each change, explain why it's necessary
5. Then proceed with implementation

This ensures we catch any misunderstandings early.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: ## Advanced Patterns ### The Socratic Method Instead of asking Claude to implement, ask questions:
Language: text
Code:
I'm considering using WebSockets for real-time notifications.

1. What are the scaling implications for 10k concurrent users?
2. How would we handle reconnection and missed messages?
3. What's the fallback for browsers that don't support WS?
4. How does this compare to Server-Sent Events for our use case?

Based on your answers, recommend an approach.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: ### Constraint Tightening Start loose, then tighten constraints: **Round 1:**
Language: text
Code:
Implement a caching layer for API responses.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: Implement a caching layer for API responses. ``` **Round 2:**
Language: text
Code:
Good start. Now add these constraints:
- TTL varies by endpoint (products: 5min, user: 30sec)
- Cache key includes user role for personalized data
- Background refresh 10 seconds before expiry

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: - Background refresh 10 seconds before expiry ``` **Round 3:**
Language: text
Code:
Almost there. Final constraints:
- Handle cache stampede (singleflight pattern)
- Add cache hit/miss metrics
- Support cache invalidation by tag

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Negative Examples Show what you don't want:
Language: text
Code:
Implement error handling for the payment API.

DON'T do this (anti-pattern):

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: console.log(e); // Silent failure   return { success: false }; // No useful error info }
Language: text
Code:
DO something like:

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Invariant Enforcement Define rules that must never be broken:
Language: text
Code:
INVARIANTS (never violate these):
1. User balance can never be negative
2. Order total must equal sum of line items + tax + shipping
3. A product cannot be in both "active" and "deleted" state
4. Authentication must happen before any API operation

When implementing features, ensure these invariants are
maintained. If a change would violate an invariant,
refuse and explain why.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ## Debugging with Advanced Prompts ### Root Cause Analysis
Language: text
Code:
Bug: Users occasionally see stale data after updating their profile.

Analyze this systematically:
1. List all caching layers between update and display
2. Identify where staleness could be introduced
3. Check for race conditions in concurrent requests
4. Examine cache invalidation logic
5. Propose fixes ordered by likelihood of being the root cause

chunks.title: TEXT Example: System Prompts and CLAUDE.md
chunks.content:
Context: 5. Propose fixes ordered by likelihood of being the root cause ``` ### Hypothesis Testing
Language: text
Code:
I suspect the memory leak is caused by event listeners not being
cleaned up in useEffect.

To test this hypothesis:
1. Find all useEffect hooks with addEventListener
2. Verify each has corresponding removeEventListener in cleanup
3. Check for closures that might prevent garbage collection
4. Suggest a test to confirm the hypothesis

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ## Debugging Workflow ### 1. Describe the Problem Be specific about what's happening:
Language: text
Code:
The login form submits but nothing happens.
Expected: Redirect to dashboard after successful login
Actual: Form clears but user stays on login page
No errors in console

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 2. Share the Error When you have error messages, share them in full:
Language: text
Code:
TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'user')
    at AuthContext.tsx:45:23
    at renderWithHooks (react-dom.development.js:14985:18)

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 3. Let Claude Investigate Claude can search for relevant code:
Language: text
Code:
Look at the AuthContext component around line 45.
What's causing the undefined 'user' error?

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ## Common Debugging Patterns ### Pattern 1: Error-First Debugging Start with the error message:
Language: text
Code:
I'm getting this error:
"ReferenceError: process is not defined"

The error occurs when I run the app in the browser.
Using Next.js 14 with App Router.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: - Explain why the error occurs ### Pattern 2: Behavior Debugging When there's no error, describe the behavior:
Language: text
Code:
The shopping cart total doesn't update when I change quantities.
- Adding items works fine
- Removing items works fine
- Changing quantity shows the new number but total stays the same

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Pattern 3: Performance Debugging For slow code or memory issues:
Language: text
Code:
The dashboard takes 5+ seconds to load.
It was fast before I added the recent activity feed.
Here's the component: src/components/RecentActivity.tsx

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Pattern 4: Regression Debugging When something that worked breaks:
Language: text
Code:
The export feature stopped working after updating to v2.0.
It was working in commit abc123.
Now it throws "Invalid file format" error.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ## Debugging Strategies ### Binary Search with Git Find when a bug was introduced:
Language: text
Code:
Help me find when this bug was introduced.
The feature works in commit from last week (abc123).
It's broken in current main (def456).
Use git bisect to narrow it down.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Minimal Reproduction Ask Claude to isolate the problem:
Language: text
Code:
The bug only happens sometimes.
Help me create a minimal reproduction case
that triggers it consistently.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Log-Based Debugging When you can't step through code:
Language: text
Code:
Add strategic console.log statements to trace
the data flow through the payment processing pipeline.
I need to see where the discount calculation goes wrong.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ## Framework-Specific Debugging ### React Debugging
Language: text
Code:
The component re-renders infinitely.
I think it's a useEffect dependency issue.
Check src/components/UserProfile.tsx

Also check if any parent components might be
causing unnecessary re-renders.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: causing unnecessary re-renders. ``` ### API Debugging
Language: text
Code:
The API returns 500 but only for certain users.
Check the error logs and identify the pattern.
Looking at src/app/api/users/[id]/route.ts

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: Looking at src/app/api/users/[id]/route.ts ``` ### State Management Debugging
Language: text
Code:
The Redux store has the correct data,
but the component shows stale values.
Check if the selector is memoized correctly.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ## Advanced Debugging Techniques ### Conditional Breakpoints with Logging
Language: text
Code:
I can't use a debugger in production.
Add conditional logging that only fires when:
- User ID is 12345
- Amount is over $100
- The discount code is "SPECIAL"

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: - The discount code is "SPECIAL" ``` ### Network Request Debugging
Language: text
Code:
The API call works in Postman but fails in the app.
Compare the exact headers, body, and request format.
Check for any request interceptors or middleware.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: Check for any request interceptors or middleware. ``` ### Memory Leak Detection
Language: text
Code:
The app slows down after extended use.
Help me identify potential memory leaks:
- Event listeners not being removed
- Subscriptions not being cancelled
- Large objects being held in closures

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ## Debugging Best Practices ### 1. Reproduce First Before fixing, ensure you can reproduce:
Language: text
Code:
Help me write a test case that reproduces this bug
so we can verify the fix works.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 2. Understand Before Fixing Ask Claude to explain the issue:
Language: text
Code:
Before we fix this, explain what's causing
the null reference at line 145.
I want to understand the root cause.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 3. One Fix at a Time Avoid multiple changes:
Language: text
Code:
Let's fix the authentication bug first.
Don't change the validation logic yet -
we need to isolate whether auth is the problem.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 4. Test the Fix After fixing:
Language: text
Code:
Now that we've fixed it:
1. Run the existing tests
2. Add a test for this specific bug
3. Check for any related edge cases

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ## Debugging Prompts Collection ### Initial Investigation
Language: text
Code:
I have a bug in [feature]. Here's what I know:
- Expected behavior: [...]
- Actual behavior: [...]
- Error message (if any): [...]
- When it started: [...]

Please investigate the relevant code and suggest
what might be causing this.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: what might be causing this. ``` ### Narrowing Down
Language: text
Code:
We've identified the bug is in the [module].
The issue happens between [step A] and [step B].
Look at the code flow and find exactly where
the data gets corrupted/lost/changed incorrectly.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: the data gets corrupted/lost/changed incorrectly. ``` ### Fix Verification
Language: text
Code:
I've applied the fix. Please:
1. Review the change for correctness
2. Check for edge cases I might have missed
3. Suggest any additional tests needed
4. Look for similar patterns elsewhere that might have the same bug

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: 4. Look for similar patterns elsewhere that might have the same bug ``` ### Root Cause Analysis
Language: text
Code:
We fixed the immediate issue, but I want to
understand how this happened.
- Why wasn't this caught earlier?
- Are there similar patterns in the codebase?
- What can we do to prevent this type of bug?

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: ## When You're Stuck ### Rubber Duck Debugging Use Claude as your rubber duck:
Language: text
Code:
Let me explain what this code is supposed to do,
step by step. Stop me if anything sounds wrong:

1. User clicks submit
2. Form data is collected into an object
3. We validate required fields
4. API call is made with the data
5. On success, we redirect to /dashboard

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: 5. On success, we redirect to /dashboard ``` ### Fresh Perspective
Language: text
Code:
I've been staring at this for hours.
Please look at the authentication flow with fresh eyes.
Something obvious might be wrong that I'm missing.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Debugging Workflow
chunks.content:
Context: Something obvious might be wrong that I'm missing. ``` ### Systematic Review
Language: text
Code:
Let's systematically check each component
in the data pipeline, from input to database:
1. Form submission
2. API route handler
3. Validation middleware
4. Database query
5. Response handling

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Quick Wins
chunks.content:
Context: ## Quick Wins ### Be Specific About Context Instead of:
Language: text
Code:
Fix the bug

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Quick Wins
chunks.content:
Context: Fix the bug ``` Try:
Language: text
Code:
Fix the bug in src/auth/login.ts where users can't log in
with email addresses containing plus signs. The validation
regex on line 42 is too restrictive.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Quick Wins
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Use File References Claude can read files directly. Reference them by path:
Language: text
Code:
Read src/components/Button.tsx and add a loading state prop

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Quick Wins
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Chain Operations Combine multiple requests:
Language: text
Code:
1. Add TypeScript types to src/utils/helpers.js
2. Rename the file to helpers.ts
3. Update all imports across the project

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Quick Wins
chunks.content:
Context: ## Pro Tips ### 1. Start with the Goal Tell Claude what you want to achieve, not just what to do:
Language: text
Code:
I want to improve the performance of the product listing page.
Currently it loads 500+ products at once and is slow.
Suggest and implement pagination or virtual scrolling.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Quick Wins
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 2. Provide Examples When asking for specific output formats:
Language: text
Code:
Generate API documentation for src/api/users.ts in this format:

## GET /users/:id
**Description**: Fetches a user by ID
**Parameters**:
- id (string): User identifier
**Response**: User object

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Quick Wins
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 3. Use Constraints Be explicit about limitations:
Language: text
Code:
Refactor this function but:
- Keep the same public API
- Don't add new dependencies
- Maintain backward compatibility with Node 16

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Quick Wins
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 4. Leverage Git Context Claude understands git. Use it:
Language: text
Code:
Review my uncommitted changes and suggest improvements

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Quick Wins
chunks.content:
Context: ``` Review my uncommitted changes and suggest improvements ```
Language: text
Code:
What changed in the last 3 commits that might have caused the test failures?

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Quick Wins
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 5. Break Down Complex Tasks For large changes, work incrementally:
Language: text
Code:
Let's add user authentication to this app. Start by:
1. Listing what we'll need to add
2. Then we'll implement each part step by step

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Quick Wins
chunks.content:

Code:
Review src/services/payment.ts for:
- Security vulnerabilities
- Error handling gaps
- Performance issues
- Code style consistency

The test file is tests/api/orders.test.ts

Add JSDoc comments to all exported functions in src/lib/

chunks.title: BASH Example: Keyboard Shortcuts

Context: ## Quick Commands ### Slash Commands Use built-in slash commands for common operations:
Language: bash
Code:
/help          # Show available commands
/clear         # Clear conversation history
/compact       # Summarize and compact context
/config        # Open configuration
/model         # Switch Claude model
/cost          # Show token usage and costs

chunks.title: BASH Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: /cost          # Show token usage and costs ``` ### File Operations
Language: bash
Code:
# Read a specific file
"Read src/index.ts"

# Read multiple files
"Read src/api/*.ts"

# Read with line numbers
"Show me lines 50-100 of src/utils/helpers.ts"

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: ## Workflow Optimization ### 1. Start with a Plan Before diving into code, ask Claude to outline the approach:
Language: text
Code:
I need to add user authentication. Before writing code:
1. List the files we'll need to create/modify
2. Outline the implementation steps
3. Identify potential challenges

Then we'll implement step by step.

chunks.title: MARKDOWN Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 2. Use Context Files Create a `.claude/context.md` file for project-specific instructions that persist across sessions:
Language: markdown
Code:
# Project Context

## Quick Commands
- "run tests" → pnpm test
- "start dev" → pnpm dev
- "deploy" → pnpm deploy:prod

## Common Tasks
- New component: Create in src/components/, add story, add test
- New API route: Create in src/app/api/, add validation, add docs

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 3. Batch Similar Operations Instead of making changes one at a time:
Language: text
Code:
Update all API route handlers in src/app/api/ to:
1. Add request validation with Zod
2. Add proper error responses
3. Add request logging
4. Add rate limiting middleware

Start with the users routes, then apply the pattern to others.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: ### 4. Create Reusable Prompts Save common prompts for quick reuse: **Code Review Prompt:**
Language: text
Code:
Review this code for:
- [ ] Type safety
- [ ] Error handling
- [ ] Performance
- [ ] Security
- [ ] Test coverage
- [ ] Documentation

Provide specific, actionable feedback.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: Provide specific, actionable feedback. ``` **PR Description Prompt:**
Language: text
Code:
Generate a PR description for these changes:
- Include a summary of what changed
- List any breaking changes
- Add testing instructions
- Note any deployment considerations

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: ## Power User Techniques ### 1. Incremental Building Build complex features piece by piece:
Language: text
Code:
Session 1: "Create the database schema for user profiles"
Session 2: "Add the API routes for CRUD operations"
Session 3: "Build the React components for the profile page"
Session 4: "Add form validation and error handling"
Session 5: "Write tests for the new functionality"

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 2. Rubber Duck Debugging Use Claude to think through problems:
Language: text
Code:
I'm stuck on this bug. Let me explain what's happening:

1. User clicks submit
2. Form data is validated (this works)
3. API call is made (this works)
4. Response comes back (this works)
5. UI doesn't update (BUG IS HERE)

Walk me through possible causes.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 3. Learning Mode Use Claude to understand unfamiliar code:
Language: text
Code:
I'm new to this codebase. Explain:
1. The overall architecture
2. How data flows from frontend to database
3. The key abstractions and patterns used
4. Where to find things I might need to modify

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 4. Template Generation Create templates for consistency:
Language: text
Code:
Generate a template for a new React component that follows
our project conventions:
- TypeScript with Props interface
- Styled with Tailwind
- Includes basic accessibility
- Has a Storybook story
- Has a test file

I'll use this as a starting point for new components.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:

Code:
/clear

Starting fresh. New task: [describe your task]
Relevant files: [list key files]

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:

Language: text
Code:
Continuing from yesterday. We were implementing user authentication.
Progress so far:
- ✅ Database schema
- ✅ API routes
- 🔄 Frontend components (in progress)
- ⏳ Testing

Let's continue with the frontend components.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Context Compaction For long sessions, compact the context:
Language: text
Code:
/compact

We've been working on the payment integration.
Key decisions made:
- Using Stripe for payments
- Webhooks for async updates
- Storing transaction logs in PostgreSQL

Continue with: webhook handler implementation

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ## Automation Ideas ### Git Workflow
Language: text
Code:
After making these changes:
1. Create a meaningful commit message
2. Show me what files changed
3. Suggest a branch name if we're not on a feature branch

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: 3. Suggest a branch name if we're not on a feature branch ``` ### Documentation
Language: text
Code:
For any new public function I write today,
automatically suggest JSDoc comments.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: automatically suggest JSDoc comments. ``` ### Testing
Language: text
Code:
After implementing each feature, suggest test cases we should add.
Focus on edge cases and error conditions.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ## Time-Saving Patterns ### 1. The "Apply Everywhere" Pattern
Language: text
Code:
I've updated the Button component to use the new design system.
Find all other components using the old button styles and update them.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: Find all other components using the old button styles and update them. ``` ### 2. The "Explain Then Execute" Pattern
Language: text
Code:
Before making changes, explain what you plan to do.
I'll confirm, then you execute.
This helps catch misunderstandings early.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: This helps catch misunderstandings early. ``` ### 3. The "Checkpoint" Pattern
Language: text
Code:
Let's checkpoint here. Summarize:
- What we've accomplished
- What's left to do
- Any blockers or concerns

Then continue with the next task.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: Then continue with the next task. ``` ### 4. The "Scope Limit" Pattern
Language: text
Code:
Let's timebox this refactoring to just the auth module.
Don't touch other parts of the codebase yet.
We'll expand scope after this is working.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Keyboard Shortcuts
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ## Daily Workflows ### Morning Routine

Good morning! Let's start the day:
1. What were we working on yesterday?
2. Any failed CI/CD pipelines to check?
3. What's the priority for today?

chunks.title: TEXT Example: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.section: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.content:
Context: 3. **Constraints** - Limitations or requirements 4. **Format** - How you want the output ### Example: Complete Prompt
Language: text
Code:
Context: I'm working on a Next.js e-commerce app with TypeScript.
The cart functionality is in src/hooks/useCart.ts.

Task: Add a function to calculate shipping costs based on
the cart total and destination country.

Constraints:
- Free shipping for orders over $100
- Use the existing CartItem type
- Don't add external dependencies

Format: Include the TypeScript types and JSDoc comments.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.section: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.content:
Context: ### 1. The Specific Request Be precise about what you want: **Vague:**
Language: text
Code:
Make the code better

chunks.title: TEXT Example: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.section: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.content:
Context: Make the code better ``` **Specific:**
Language: text
Code:
Refactor the fetchUsers function in src/api/users.ts to:
- Use async/await instead of .then() chains
- Add proper error handling with typed errors
- Include retry logic for network failures (max 3 retries)

chunks.title: TEXT Example: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.section: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 2. The Contextual Request Provide relevant background:
Language: text
Code:
Our app uses a custom authentication system where:
- JWT tokens are stored in httpOnly cookies
- Refresh tokens are rotated on each use
- Sessions expire after 24 hours of inactivity

Given this context, implement a middleware that validates
the session and refreshes tokens when needed.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.section: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 3. The Constrained Request Set clear boundaries:
Language: text
Code:
Create a date formatting utility that:
- Works without any external libraries
- Supports ISO 8601, US, and European formats
- Is tree-shakeable (separate named exports)
- Has full TypeScript types
- Is under 50 lines of code

chunks.title: TEXT Example: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.section: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 4. The Iterative Request Build on previous work:
Language: text
Code:
That implementation looks good. Now:
1. Add unit tests for the edge cases we discussed
2. Handle the timezone conversion issue
3. Add a caching layer to avoid repeated calculations

chunks.title: TEXT Example: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.section: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### 5. The Comparative Request When you want options:
Language: text
Code:
Show me 3 different ways to implement state management
for this form. Compare:
1. React useState
2. React useReducer
3. A form library like React Hook Form

Include pros/cons for each approach given our requirements.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.section: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.content:
Context: ## Advanced Techniques ### Chain of Thought Ask Claude to think through the problem:
Language: text
Code:
Before implementing, walk me through:
1. What are the potential edge cases?
2. What existing code might be affected?
3. What's the simplest solution that works?

Then implement based on your analysis.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.section: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Role Assignment Set expectations with a role:
Language: text
Code:
Act as a senior security engineer reviewing this authentication code.
Focus on:
- OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities
- Token handling best practices
- Input validation gaps

chunks.title: TEXT Example: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.section: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
chunks.content:

Language: text
Code:
Convert these function names to our naming convention:

Input: getUserData → Output: fetchUserById
Input: saveSettings → Output: updateUserSettings
Input: removeItem → Output: deleteCartItem

Now convert these:
- loadProducts
- createOrder
- updateProfile

## Summary

## Recommendations
1. [First recommendation]
2. [Second recommendation]

4. No results appear (should show 15 items)

Relevant files:
- src/pages/search.tsx
- src/api/search.ts
- src/utils/query.ts

Review this file for bugs, security issues, and improvements:
[paste your code or reference a file]

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Why Use Claude for Code Review?
chunks.section: Why Use Claude for Code Review?
chunks.content:
Context: ## Review Strategies ### Strategy 1: Full PR Review Review all changes in a pull request:
Language: text
Code:
Review all the changes in this PR. Look for:
1. Bugs and logic errors
2. Security vulnerabilities
3. Performance issues
4. Code style consistency
5. Missing error handling

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Why Use Claude for Code Review?
chunks.section: Why Use Claude for Code Review?
chunks.content:
Context: 3. Provide categorized feedback ### Strategy 2: Security-Focused Review For security-critical code:
Language: text
Code:
Perform a security audit on the authentication module.
Focus on:
- SQL injection vulnerabilities
- XSS attack vectors
- Authentication bypass risks
- Sensitive data exposure
- CSRF protection

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Why Use Claude for Code Review?
chunks.section: Why Use Claude for Code Review?
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Strategy 3: Performance Review For performance-critical sections:
Language: text
Code:
Review this code for performance issues:
- N+1 query problems
- Memory leaks
- Unnecessary re-renders (React)
- Inefficient algorithms
- Missing caching opportunities

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Why Use Claude for Code Review?
chunks.section: Why Use Claude for Code Review?
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Strategy 4: Incremental Review Review specific changes:
Language: text
Code:
I just added error handling to the payment processor.
Review only the new error handling code for:
- Edge cases I might have missed
- Error message clarity
- Logging completeness

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Why Use Claude for Code Review?

Language: text

Review this code against the following checklist:

## Correctness
- [ ] Logic errors
- [ ] Off-by-one errors
- [ ] Null/undefined handling
- [ ] Edge cases

## Security
- [ ] Input validation
- [ ] SQL injection
- [ ] XSS vulnerabilities
- [ ] Authentication/authorization
- [ ] Sensitive data handling

## Performance
- [ ] Algorithm efficiency
- [ ] Database queries
- [ ] Memory usage
- [ ] Caching

## Maintainability
- [ ] Code clarity
- [ ] Naming conventions
- [ ] Documentation
- [ ] Test coverage

## Error Handling
- [ ] Try/catch blocks
- [ ] Error messages
- [ ] Logging
- [ ] User feedback

Context: ## Integrating with Git Workflows ### Pre-Commit Review Review staged changes before committing:
Language: text
Code:
Review my staged changes (git diff --staged).
Are there any issues I should fix before committing?

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Why Use Claude for Code Review?
chunks.section: Why Use Claude for Code Review?
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### PR Description Generation Generate PR descriptions from code changes:
Language: text
Code:
Generate a PR description for these changes.
Include:
- Summary of what changed
- Why these changes were made
- Testing performed
- Any breaking changes

chunks.title: BASH Example: Why Use Claude for Code Review?
chunks.section: Why Use Claude for Code Review?
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Automated Review with Hooks Create a pre-push hook that asks Claude to review:
Language: bash
Code:
# .claude/commands/review-changes.md
Review the changes between HEAD and origin/main.
Provide a summary of:
1. Critical issues that must be fixed
2. Warnings that should be addressed
3. Minor suggestions for improvement

Language: text
Code:
This is a payment processing module for an e-commerce site.
Users can pay with credit cards or PayPal.
Review for PCI compliance and security issues.

Language: text
Code:
Review against our team standards:
- Use TypeScript strict mode
- All functions must have JSDoc comments
- No console.log in production code
- Error messages must be user-friendly

Language: text
Code:
Categorize issues by severity:
- CRITICAL: Must fix before merge
- WARNING: Should fix soon
- SUGGESTION: Nice to have

Language: text
Code:
For each issue found, provide:
1. The problem
2. Why it matters
3. How to fix it
4. Example code if applicable

Language: text
Code:
Add comprehensive JSDoc comments to all exported functions
in the utils directory. Include:
- Description
- @param tags with types and descriptions
- @returns tag with type and description
- @throws tag for error conditions
- @example with usage code

chunks.title: TYPESCRIPT Example: Types of Documentation
TYPESCRIPT Example: Types of Documentation
chunks.content:
Context: } ``` **After:**
Language: typescript
Code:
/**
 * Formats a number as currency according to locale conventions.
 *
 * @param {number} amount - The numeric amount to format
 * @param {string} currency - ISO 4217 currency code (e.g., 'USD', 'EUR')
 * @param {string} [locale='en-US'] - BCP 47 locale identifier
 * @returns {string} Formatted currency string
 * @throws {RangeError} If currency code is invalid
 *
 * @example
 * formatCurrency(1234.56, 'USD', 'en-US')
 * // Returns: '$1,234.56'
 *
 * @example
 * formatCurrency(1234.56, 'EUR', 'de-DE')
 * // Returns: '1.234,56 EUR'
 */
export function formatCurrency(
  amount: number,
  currency: string,
  locale: string = 'en-US'
): string {
  return new Intl.NumberFormat(locale, {
    style: 'currency',
    currency
  }).format(amount);
}

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Types of Documentation
chunks.content:
Context: } ``` ### Python Docstrings
Language: text
Code:
Add Google-style docstrings to all functions in the services module.
Include Args, Returns, Raises, and Examples sections.

chunks.title: PYTHON Example: Types of Documentation
chunks.content:
Context: Include Args, Returns, Raises, and Examples sections. ``` **Example Output:**
Language: python
Code:
def calculate_discount(price: float, percentage: float, max_discount: float = None) -> float:
    """Calculate discounted price with optional maximum limit.

    Applies a percentage discount to the original price. If max_discount
    is specified, the discount amount will not exceed this value.

    Args:
        price: Original price in dollars.
        percentage: Discount percentage (0-100).
        max_discount: Maximum discount amount in dollars. Defaults to None.

    Returns:
        The final price after applying the discount.

    Raises:
        ValueError: If price is negative or percentage is outside 0-100.

    Examples:
        >>> calculate_discount(100.0, 20)
        80.0

        >>> calculate_discount(100.0, 50, max_discount=25.0)
        75.0
    """

Language: markdown
Code:
## Environment Variables

### Required Variables

| Variable | Description | Example |
|----------|-------------|---------|
| `DATABASE_URL` | PostgreSQL connection string | `postgres://user:pass@localhost:5432/mydb` |
| `JWT_SECRET` | Secret key for JWT signing | `your-256-bit-secret` |

### Optional Variables

| Variable | Description | Default |
|----------|-------------|---------|
| `PORT` | Server port | `3000` |
| `LOG_LEVEL` | Logging verbosity | `info` |
| `RATE_LIMIT` | Requests per minute | `100` |

chunks.content:
Context: ``` ## Documentation Workflows ### Workflow 1: New Project Setup
Language: text
Code:
1. Generate README.md with project overview
2. Create CONTRIBUTING.md with guidelines
3. Generate API.md for endpoint documentation
4. Create CHANGELOG.md template

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Types of Documentation
chunks.content:
Context: 4. Create CHANGELOG.md template ``` ### Workflow 2: Code Documentation Sprint
Language: text
Code:
Day 1: Document all public APIs
Day 2: Add inline comments to complex functions
Day 3: Create architecture overview
Day 4: Write deployment guide
Day 5: Review and refine all docs

chunks.title: BASH Example: Types of Documentation
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ### Workflow 3: Continuous Documentation Set up a pre-commit hook:
Language: bash
Code:
# .claude/commands/update-docs.md
Check if any exported functions are missing documentation.
If found, generate appropriate JSDoc/docstrings.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Types of Documentation
chunks.content:
Context: ``` ## Best Practices ### 1. Provide Context
Language: text
Code:
This is a payment processing library used by e-commerce sites.
Users are developers integrating payments into their apps.
Generate documentation assuming intermediate JavaScript knowledge.

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Types of Documentation
chunks.content:
Context: Generate documentation assuming intermediate JavaScript knowledge. ``` ### 2. Specify Audience
Language: text
Code:
Generate documentation for:
- Audience: Backend developers
- Experience level: Intermediate
- Primary use case: Building REST APIs

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Types of Documentation
chunks.content:
Context: - Primary use case: Building REST APIs ``` ### 3. Maintain Consistency
Language: text
Code:
Follow these documentation standards:
- Use present tense ("Returns" not "Will return")
- Use active voice ("Call this function" not "This function should be called")
- Include code examples for every function
- Document error conditions

chunks.title: TEXT Example: Types of Documentation
chunks.content:
Context: - Document error conditions ``` ### 4. Keep It Updated
Language: text
Code:
Review existing documentation and update it to match
the current implementation. Flag any outdated sections.
